revised_title: The Electromotive Properties of the Skin of the Common Eel: Glandular Processes and Excitatory Variations
tldr: This study investigates the electromotive properties of the common eel's skin, examining the role of glandular processes and secretory elements in generating electrical potential. The research demonstrates that mechanical, electrical, and thermal stimulation can excite variations in the skin's electromotive force, supporting the hypothesis that both the resting and action currents originate from glandular sources.
